First line for mild depression in epilepsy:
- Non‑drug care: psychoeducation, CBT/behavioral activation, regular exercise, sleep and stress management; check/adjust antiseizure meds that may worsen mood.
- If meds are needed, start a low‑risk SSRI at low dose (sertraline, citalopram, or escitalopram), increase slowly, and monitor interactions.
- Avoid bupropion, clomipramine, maprotiline, and high‑dose TCAs (higher seizure risk).

References:
- NICE. Depression in adults: treatment and management (NG222), 2022.
- Specialist Pharmacy Service (UK). Using antidepressants in people with epilepsy, 2023.
- Mula M. Depression in epilepsy: update. Epilepsy & Behavior, 2019.

1.answer:
First line: start an SSRI (sertraline, citalopram, escitalopram, fluoxetine). If not tolerated/ineffective, use an SNRI (venlafaxine/duloxetine) or mirtazapine. Combine with psychotherapy (CBT or IPT). For very severe, psychotic, or suicidal depression, consider ECT (safe in epilepsy). Avoid bupropion and clomipramine/high‑dose TCAs. Check antiseizure‑drug interactions; sertraline/escitalopram have low risk.

References:
- ILAE Task Force. Treatment of depression in adults with epilepsy. Epilepsia. 2021.
- NICE Guideline NG222: Depression in adults. 2022.

2.answer:
- First-line: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) tailored to epilepsy (thoughts, mood, seizure fears).
- Mindfulness-based CBT (e.g., Project UPLIFT) via group, phone, or online.
- Behavioral activation or problem-solving therapy; interpersonal therapy when relationships drive mood.
- Psychoeducation/self-management (stress, sleep, medication, stigma), include family when helpful.
- Coordinate with neurology; screen for suicide risk.

References:
- Michael BD et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2014.
- Kanner AM et al. ILAE recommendations, Epilepsia. 2021.
- Thompson NJ et al. Project UPLIFT RCT, J Consult Clin Psychol. 2010.

- Ongoing: CBT or IPT plus SSRI/SNRI (sertraline, citalopram/escitalopram); avoid bupropion/TCAs; monitor suicidality. Reassess antiseizure drugs—reduce those worsening mood; lamotrigine may help. For severe/refractory suicidality: ECT or rTMS. Coordinate neurology–psychiatry care.

References:

- NICE NG217. Epilepsies: diagnosis and management. 2022.

First-line: combine an SSRI (sertraline/escitalopram) with a low‑seizure‑risk antipsychotic (quetiapine, risperidone, aripiprazole). ECT if severe, suicidal, or not improving; usually safe in epilepsy with your seizure‑medicine team. Avoid bupropion, clomipramine, high‑dose TCAs, and clozapine. Check for interactions with seizure medicines; consider lamotrigine/valproate for mood help.

References:
- NICE Guideline NG222: Depression in adults (2022)
- Kanner AM. Nat Rev Neurol. 2016;12:106–116
- Mula M. Epilepsia. 2013;54(Suppl 1):13–22

5.answer:
- First, check adherence, side effects, and drug interactions; optimize the dose/time (usually 6–8 weeks).
- Then switch to: another SSRI (sertraline, escitalopram), an SNRI (venlafaxine, duloxetine), or mirtazapine/vortioxetine.
- Augment: add lamotrigine (helps mood and seizures) or low‑dose quetiapine; add CBT.
- If still resistant: rTMS or ECT can be used with precautions; VNS may help when used for epilepsy.
- Avoid bupropion, clomipramine, maprotiline, high‑dose TCAs.

References:
- Specialist Pharmacy Service. Using antidepressants in people with epilepsy, 2023.
- ILAE Commission guidance on antidepressants in epilepsy, Epilepsia, 2021.
- Kanner AM. Depression in epilepsy: treatment review, Lancet Neurol, 2016.

- Continue the antidepressant at the dose that worked for 6–12 months after you feel well.
- If relapse risk is high (2 or more past episodes, chronic/severe depression, or major stress), keep treatment for at least 2 years; some people may need long‑term maintenance.
- In epilepsy, never stop suddenly. Taper slowly over weeks–months to avoid withdrawal and possible seizure worsening; check for drug interactions.

- NICE. Depression in adults: treatment and management (NG222), 2022.
- ILAE Task Force. Management of depression in people with epilepsy, Epilepsia, 2022.
- VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guideline for MDD, 2022.

7.answer:
Preferred: For depression in epilepsy, use SSRIs (sertraline, citalopram/escitalopram) or SNRIs; for bipolar depression, favor antiepileptic mood stabilizers (lamotrigine; valproate). Lithium isn’t first-line; reserve for clear bipolar disorder or suicidality. If used, keep low levels (0.6–0.8 mmol/L), monitor kidneys/thyroid/sodium, avoid dehydration and interactions (NSAIDs, ACE-Is, diuretics, carbamazepine, topiramate). Consider psychotherapy, ECT, or VNS if refractory.

References:
- Kanner AM. Epilepsy Behav. 2016.
- Mula M, Kanner AM. Epilepsy Behav. 2020.
- Yatham LN et al. CANMAT/ISBD Bipolar Guidelines, 2018.

8.answer:
Antipsychotics are not first-line for depression in epilepsy. Use them only if there is psychotic depression or comorbid psychosis/agitation. Prefer lower–seizure-risk drugs (aripiprazole, risperidone; haloperidol). Use quetiapine/olanzapine cautiously; avoid clozapine if possible. Start low, go slow, and watch interactions (carbamazepine lowers antipsychotic levels; clozapine+carbamazepine is unsafe; valproate may raise some levels). Combine with SSRIs/SNRIs and therapy; consider ECT for severe cases.

References:
- Mula M, Schmitz B. Depression in epilepsy: evidence-based treatment. Epilepsia, 2009–2013 reviews.
- NICE NG217: Epilepsies: diagnosis and management (2022, updated).
- Alper K. Seizure risk with antipsychotics. J Clin Psychiatry, 2007.

10.answer:
- ECT is appropriate for severe or treatment‑resistant depression in people with epilepsy, with precautions.
- Continue anti‑seizure medicines; avoid abrupt stopping. If ECT seizures are too short, consider holding only the morning dose of benzodiazepines (or other strong seizure‑threshold raisers) and resume after.
- Prefer right‑unilateral ultrabrief‑pulse ECT; use EEG monitoring and have rescue benzodiazepines available.
- Seizure worsening is uncommon; coordination with neurology/psychiatry is essential. Consider rTMS or ketamine if ECT unsuitable.

References:
- American Psychiatric Association. The Practice of Electroconvulsive Therapy. 3rd ed., 2008.
- Royal College of Psychiatrists. The ECT Handbook. 4th ed., 2019.
- Epilepsy & Behavior review: Electroconvulsive therapy in patients with epilepsy (2016).

11.answer:
Bright light therapy can help depression and is usually okay in epilepsy if you’re not photosensitive. Use a flicker‑free, steady light box (around 10,000 lux) in the morning, start low (5–10 minutes) and increase to 20–30 minutes while monitoring for auras, jerks, or seizure change. Avoid flashing/patterned lights; stop if symptoms occur and consult neurology. If photosensitive or seizures are unstable, prefer CBT and SSRIs/SNRIs; avoid bupropion (raises seizure risk).

References:
- Lam RW et al. JAMA Psychiatry. 2016.
- Golden RN et al. Am J Psychiatry. 2005.
- Kasteleijn-Nolst Trenité DGA et al. Epilepsia. 2012.

Make exercise part of care. Do ≥150 minutes/week of moderate aerobic (walk, bike) plus 2 days/week of strength; add balance/flexibility. Exercise is usually safe in epilepsy, can lift mood, and may even lower seizures. Start low and go slow; if seizures aren’t controlled, exercise with supervision; avoid unsupervised swimming, heights, scuba. Keep good sleep and hydration. Continue talk therapy or antidepressants and antiseizure medicines; track mood and seizures.

References: Capovilla G et al. Epilepsia 2016; Cooney GM et al. Cochrane 2013/2019; WHO Physical Activity Guidelines 2020.

- Depression only: use implanted VNS for chronic treatment‑resistant depression after multiple failed treatments (often after ECT/TMS); benefits build over months as an add‑on.

Recommendations:
- Depression with epilepsy: Standard FDA-cleared rTMS to the left frontal area can be used; keep antiseizure meds, avoid sleep loss, and follow safety rules.
- Epilepsy: Low-frequency (≤1 Hz) rTMS over the seizure area may give modest, short-term seizure reduction; consider only as an add-on in experienced/research centers, not routine care.

References:
- Lefaucheur et al., Clin Neurophysiol, 2020 (rTMS guidelines)
- Rossi et al., Clin Neurophysiol, 2021 (TMS safety)
- Cochrane Review, 2016 (rTMS for epilepsy)
